summary: This is a Federal Bureau of Prisons Program Statement (P6541.02) establishing procedures for inmate access to Over-the-Counter (OTC) medications. It details how inmates can purchase medications through the commissary or obtain them for free if indigent, and outlines the roles of health services and administrative staff in managing the program.

events.title: Issuance of OTC Medication Program Statement
events.description: The Federal Bureau of Prisons issues Program Statement P6541.02, establishing updated procedures for inmate access to Over-the-Counter medications.

events.title: Rescission of Previous OTC Medication Directive
events.description: Directive P6541.01 on Over-the-Counter Medications is rescinded and replaced by the new Program Statement.

keyFacts: The document is a Bureau of Prisons policy (P6541.02) dated November 17, 2004, governing inmate access to Over-the-Counter medications.
Inmates can buy OTC medications at the commissary or obtain them for free at sick call/pharmacy if they are deemed indigent (having less than $6 in their trust fund for 30 days).
The policy aims to improve inmate access to OTC medications while conserving health services resources for more serious medical needs.
Institutions must stock at least 25 OTC medications and establish procedures for indigent inmates to receive up to two medications per week.
The document rescinds a previous directive (P6541.01 from September 10, 2003) and references other BOP manuals and American Correctional Association standards.
